body:
Could you set the time_completions setting to true please and show me the console output?

Do you have a more specific example of when this happens? What exactly is your sublimeclang_options setting and which file specifically are you typing in and what are you typing?

Here's what I tried:

llvm.sublime-project:
```json
{
	"folders":
	[
		{
			"path": "."
		}
	],
    "settings":
    {
        "sublimeclang_options":
        [
            "-I${project_path:include}",
            "-I${project_path:build}/include"
        ],
        "sublimeclang_options_script": "python ${project_path:cmake_options_script.py}"
    }
}
```
cmake_options_script.py is https://gist.github.com/3944250

I opened up Use.cpp and typed inside of the Use::swap method and got:
```
found fast completions
TU: 0.762224, Comp: 9.186983, Filter: 0.207901, Tot: 10.157108 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.579834, Comp: 7.090092, Filter: 0.123978, Tot: 7.793903 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.546932, Comp: 5.559921, Filter: 0.027895, Tot: 6.134748 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.411987, Comp: 3.721952, Filter: 0.026941, Tot: 4.160881 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.409126, Comp: 5.276918, Filter: 0.056982, Tot: 5.743027 ms
```

I opened up Globals.cpp and typed inside of the GlobalVariable::setInitializer method and got:
```
found fast completions
TU: 0.653028, Comp: 63.762903, Filter: 0.871897, Tot: 65.287828 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.432014, Comp: 49.400091, Filter: 0.683069, Tot: 50.515175 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.596046, Comp: 51.409006, Filter: 0.748873, Tot: 52.753925 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.436068, Comp: 48.929930, Filter: 0.756025, Tot: 50.122023 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.539064, Comp: 48.946857, Filter: 0.708103, Tot: 50.194025 ms
found fast completions
TU: 0.445127, Comp: 9.505987, Filter: 0.096083, Tot: 10.047197 ms
```

So I'm not able to reproduce the issue. Please provide more details.
Thanks, I can reproduce that, I'll have a look at what's going on. FWIW disabling the "fast" completions in this instance is much, much quicker at completing at ~300ms :)
That issue should now be fixed. Please let me know if you are still seeing these extreme freezes.

Appears fixed.

On my smaller project which was still seeing significant (1.5-2s) stalls, it's now ~80ms, and while the LLVM example sited is still less than ideal (since it blocks the UI/keyboard input), it is a much more reasonable ~550ms with "fast completions" still enabled.


On Oct 25, 2012, at 8:39 AM, Fredrik Ehnbom <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> That issue should now be fixed. Please let me know if you are still seeing these extreme freezes.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
> 
>

FYI SublimeClang only triggers complete operations itself in specific situations when it think it can complete. All other complete operations are triggered by ST2 so you might want to tweak the ST2 setting "auto_complete_delay" from its default of 50ms for the projects where you find that typing is blocked.

Closing issue. Please reopen or file a new issue if you find more instances where the complete operation is insanely expensive.
If the translation unit is None it wasn't possible for clang to parse the source code. Try fiddling with the compilation options you've provided until the message goes away.

OK, thanks.
I will do that.

Just for the record: 
My problem was caused by different version of libclang installed simultaneously on my Ubuntu (in /usr/lib and /usr/local/lib).
After removing one of them the problem seems to be solved and the `tu is None...` messages are gone.
Thanks for your help again, and congratulations for your awesome work. SublimeClang is the only reason I use Sublime Text.
